While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from breeding pigs. Marilyn has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Marilyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marilyn is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be Marilyn's first loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition fees. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Sakina's Group

texts.en:
Sakina has been living in an area of city Kasur named Kot Fateh Naaz Khan for more than 15 years with her family. Kasur is a small city of Punjab and is known for its leather industry in Pakistan. 
In order to help share her family's financial burden, Sakina operates her embroidery business by collecting orders from her neighboring clients. She completes a fully embroidered dress in 7 days and earns almost PKRs 500-700 profit on each dress. Her earning encourages her to work with more dedication and enthusiasm.  
Her husband, S. M., is a rickshaw driver by trade.  He provides transport services to his passengers and earns income for the family. 
She has given birth to three sons and three daughters. Her two elder sons are illiterate and do different works to financially support the family. Her eldest son performs his duty as a rickshaw driver. He drives a rickshaw on rent while the second son works at a gas station for a very little income. 
Due to their jobs, Sakina is able to send her younger children to school. She wishes that they could complete their education and make their futures bright.  
She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her eldest son. With the loan, her son will buy a rickshaw. If he has his own rickshaw, he will be able to work longer hours and earn a good income. 
She is very hopeful that by purchasing a rickshaw for her son, her family’s living standard will be improved. 
She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 3rd loan application. In previous loan years, she has proved herself as a responsible client and paid her installments on time.

loans.use: To buy a rickshaw

loans.name: Lucy Wambui

texts.en:
Lucy has practiced farming in Olkalou since the year 1999.  She is 54 years old, married to James Ngethe, and they have two children.

She was introduced to KADET LTD  by her friend and this will be her first loan.  She plans to use the loan amount to plant more potatoes in her farm.

In future, she plans to start other businesses in town and she is currently thinking of opening a clothes shop.

loans.use: To plant potatoes in her farm

loans.name: Samuel Wambugu

texts.en:
Samuel has practiced farming in Olkalou since 1993. He is 42 years old, married to Hannah Njoki, and they have two children.

He was introduced to KADET LTD by his friend and this will be his second loan.  He repaid his previous loan well and in good time.  He plans to use the loan amount to harvest and market the maize from his farm.

In future, Samuel hopes to build rental houses and this will increase his income.

loans.use: To harvest and market the maize he planted

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph L. is from the village of Mercy Village, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. He is 37 years old. Joseph is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Joseph owns & operates a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from providing "motorela" or tricycle services to local community members. Joseph has been engaged in his business for over 10 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Joseph joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Joseph is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase tools for the maintenance of the "motorela" or tricycle. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Joseph from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.name: Leticia

texts.en:
Leticia L. is 61 years old, married and has five adult-aged children. She is from the village of Matusalem, a part of Roxas municipality, Isabela province on the Luzon islands. Leticia runs a retail store from which she primarily sells alcoholic beverages including beer and wine to the local community. Leticia has been in business for over five years and earns approximately 3500 PHP a month.

In 2009, Leticia joined ASKI to gain access to its financial services. She successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from ASKI that was used to purchase additional alcoholic beverages to sell. Leticia is requesting a new loan, her third from ASKI, of 10,000 PHP that will be used to purchase new beverages to expand her inventory. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business.

About ASKI:

Alalay sa Kaunlaran, Inc., or ASKI, is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen and -women, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.name: Sari Kencana Group

texts.en: Jro Nyoman T.'s main source of income comes from raising pigs for sale. She is a 31-year-old woman living in the town of Melaya, Bali. Jro Nyoman is married and has two school-aged children. She has been in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 500,000 Indonesian rupiah (IDR) a month. In 2010, Jro Nyoman joined MUK to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Jro Nyoman has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1,000,000 IDR from MUK which was used to purchase livestock to raise and sell. She is now requesting a new loan of 1,000,000 IDR which will be used to purchase livestock to raise and sell. This will be her second loan from MUK. Jro Nyoman plans to use additional income to pay the tuition fees of her children. Jro Nyoman is the leader of a 10 member group accessing a loan offered by MUK. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is "Sari Kencana" (PK-10333). About MUK The mission of Koperasi Mitra Usaha Kecil (MUK) is to assist small businesses in Bali by providing training, business consultation and loans, thereby helping the owners and their families improve their everyday lives. Jro Nyoman T. (0) merupakan 31 tahun wanita. Dia (perempuan) tinggal di kota Melaya - Bali. Jro Nyoman adalah pemimpin kelompok sebuah kelompok peminjam yang terdiri atas 10 anggota. Meskipun setiap anggota kelompok menerima pinjaman perorangan, mereka semua bertanggung jawab untuk mengembalikan pinjaman rekan anggota kelompok mereka jika ada yang menunggak atau gagal membayar. Nama resmi kelompok peminjam ini adalah Sari Kencana (PK-10333). Meskipun bukan satu-satunya sarana untuk menghasilkan pendapatan, sumber utama penghasilan bisnis tersebut terutama berasal dari beternak babi untuk dijual. Jro Nyoman sudah menjalankan bisnis ini selama lebih dari 10 tahun. Dari kegiatan-kegiatan ini, Jro Nyoman menghasilkan sekitar 0,500 IDR. Dalam 2010, Jro Nyoman bergabung MUK untuk mendapatkan akses ke layanan keuangan untuk membantu meningkatkan -nya kondisi kehidupan dan kemampuan untuk menjalankan kegiatan bisnis. Jro Nyoman telah berhasil melunasi pinjaman sebelumnya sebesar 1.000.000 IDR dari MUK. Pinjaman sebelumnya ini digunakan untuk membeli bibit ternak untuk dibesarkan & dijual di masa mendatang. Dia (perempuan) sekarang meminta pinjaman baru sebesar 1.000.000 IDR. Pinjaman ini akan menjadi 2nd pinjaman yang diambil oleh peminjam dari MUK. Tentang MUK: Misi Koperasi Mitra Usaha Kecil (MUK) adalah untuk membantu usaha kecil di Bali dengan memberikan perlatihan, konsultasi bisnis, dan pinjaman uang, dengan demikian membantu pemilik usaha dan keluarga mereka memperbaiki hidup sehari-hari.

loans.use: To purchase livestock to raise and sell

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 22-year-old Lebanese man living with his parents and one brother. He is engaged to a girl from his town, and they are planning to get married soon. Despite his young age, he has opened a barber shop in his town after getting the needed experience of seven years working in another local barber shop. Always presenting new styles to his clients, he works hard to earn a good income in preparation for his coming married life.

Today, he is requesting a loan of 1200 USD from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to add new décor to his shop to attract new customers. In the future, he hopes to open a new branch and build a good reputation in his field.

loans.name: Catalina

texts.en:
Catalina Y. is from the village of Matusalem. She is 58 years old and married with seven school-aged children. To make a living, Catalina owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income from the business comes primarily from selling seafood products, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. Catalina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI that was used to purchase additional products to sell. Catalina is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items and expand the number of products her retail store offers. This loan will be the ninth loan taken out by Catalina from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business.

loans.name: Haleema Sadiq's Group

texts.en:
Haleema lives with her family in a two-room brick house in the city of Kasur which is located in Punjab, Pakistan, and is famous for its leather industry. She is married to S., who is a government employee whose job provides a meager income.  In order to support her husband financially, Haleema has an embroidery business and embroiders dresses that are custom ordered by her neighbors. Her earnings allow her to pay the utility bills for her family. Haleema’s husband respects her for her helping and caring nature towards the family. Haleema has two sons and a daughter. Her elder son also works as a government employee and her daughter helps her in her embroidery business.  Her youngest son is eight and illiterate.

Haleema has applied for a loan from the Kiva partner Asasah to improve her embroidery business. She is a previous loan recipient from Asasah and this is her second loan application. She is a responsible client who has paid installments on time and never missed any meetings. With this loan, she will purchase embroidery material such as beads, colored thread, sketches and bulk quantity clothes for embroidery.  She is very hopeful that this investment will improve her business and that her monthly income will grow. She has been doing this business for the past five years and is confident about its bright future.

loans.use: To buy materials for embroidery business

loans.name: Lach

texts.en:
Mrs. Lach S. is 29 years of age and is a resident of Takhmao. She has a life partner in her husband, who works in the construction field. The couple has a lovely baby boy.

Lach’s work involves receiving pieces of clothing from garment factories and arranging them in sets for a fee. In addition, she also buys clothing and turns pieces into cradles and mats, which she sells to middlemen who then take them to sell at retail at the market.

Lach S. is requesting a loan to buy more clothing to make cradles and mats to satisfy the needs of her customers.

loans.use: To buy more clothing to make cradles and mats

loans.name: Khursheed Muhammad Ramzan's Group

texts.en:
Twenty-five years ago Khursheed M. R. moved to Kasur, a city located in Punjab and known for its leather industry in Pakistan. Then a few years ago she lost her husband to a sudden death, so she is now a widow. She lives in a two-room brick house with her family. She couldn’t send her children to school due to poor financial conditions, so she taught her daughters the art of embroidery, which they now do to earn money for the family. She also has a son who runs a grocery shop in the market from which he sells daily use items to his customers.

Khursheed’s children are very obedient and mind everything she says. They respect her very much and take care of her in the way she takes care of them. They like to give her every happiness in life so she never thinks about her loss.

Khursheed has applied for a loan, her fifth from Asasah, for her son’s grocery business. He has been in this business for the past ten years. With the loan he will buy grocery items such as rice, lentils, cooking oil and spices, etc. in bulk quantity for his shop. Khursheed is hopeful that this investment will yield a positive impact on her son’s business. She herself has responsibly paid her previous loan installments every year and attended every meeting.

loans.use: To buy groceries in bulk for her son's grocery shop

texts.en:
Rahab is 29 years old. She has been planting potatoes in Olkalou town, both for domestic and commercial use, since 2001.The climatic condition of this area is very suitable for potatoes and this is a real stable food in Kenya. She was introduced to KADET by a friend and this will be her second loan. She repaid her first loan well and in good time. She plans to plant more potatoes on her farm as this is the planting season.

In the future, Rahab hopes to build a school in Olkalou and help the less fortunate by giving them free education.

loans.use: To plant more potatoes on her farm

loans.name: Chhorn

texts.en:
Chhorn C., 40, is married and lives with her husband and four children in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia – an area known for rubber plantations. C. and her husband are farmers, earning about $5 US per day. Two of her children are employed in the factories, earning $3 US each per day. The family has to spend $40 US on food, $5 US on electricity and water supplies and $10 US on other necessary expenses every month.

C. is requesting a loan of $500 US to purchase more equipment for her daughter to improve her hairdressing business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy hairdressing equipment

loans.name: Chhorn

texts.en:
Chhorn M., 45, is married and lives with her husband and a child in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia – an area known for rubber plantations. M. and her husband raise and sell fish, earning about $15 US per day. The family has to spend $50 US on food, $20 US on children's education, and $15 US on other necessary expenses every month.

M. is requesting a loan of $500 US to purchase more fish to resell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more fish to resell

loans.name: Blesida

texts.en: Blesida C. owns and operates a sari-sari (variety retail shop) selling canned goods, coffee and chocolate drink in sachet, as well as chicharron (fried pork rinds) in her community. She is 52 years old, married and has six grown-up children. She is from the village of Poblacion, Valencia City, Bukidnon. Blesida has been in her business for over six years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2010, Blesida joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Blesida is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use additional income to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. loans.name: Sen

texts.en:
Sen C., 45, is married and lives with her husband and a child in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia – an area known for rubber plantations. C. sells medicines, earning about $1.50 US per day. Her husband is a motorbike repairman, earning $2.20 US per day. The family has to spend $40 US on food, $1 US on electricity and water supplies, and $17 US on other necessary expenses every month. 

C. is requesting a loan of $300 US to purchase a motorbike for family use. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for family use

loans.name: Hafeez's Group

texts.en:
Hafeez is a resident of Khanewal, which is a small city located in Punjab, Pakistan, that is famous for its agriculture industry. She is 30 years old and a mother of three sons and a daughter. She is unable to provide an education to her children due to the poor financial condition of her family. 

Her husband, M., is a private entrepreneur and is involved in a dairy business. For this purpose, he keeps a buffalo at his home. That gives him almost 8kg milk, which he sells for 45 Pakistan rupees (PKRs) per kg. In this way, his daily income becomes PKRs 360, which helps him to manage the financial circle of his family.  

Hafeez is a housewife. She prefers to stay at home and take care of her family. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan, her husband will buy another buffalo for his dairy business and increase the milk productivity.  

Hafeez is hopeful that her husband will successfully be able to increase his profits by utilizing the money positively. She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her second loan application. In the previous year, she has built good credit behavior and never missed any meetings. 

Note: In the photo, the lady who is holding the book (called the Asasah Passbook) in her hands is Hafeez.

loans.use: To buy another buffalo for a dairy business

loans.name: Meoung

texts.en:
Meoung S., 56, is widowed and lives in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia – an area known for rubber plantations. S. is a farmer and raises chickens, earning about $0.60 US per day. Her child is a tailor in the city, earning $100.00 US per month to help cover the family expenses. The family has to spend $40.00 US on food, $1.00 on electricity and water supplies, and $19.00 on other necessary expenses every month.

S. is requesting a loan of $500.00 to build a chicken cage and buy more chickens to raise. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To build a chicken cage and buy more chickens to raise

loans.name: Sharonaliza

texts.en:
Sharonaliza S. is from the village of Matusalem. She is 25 years old. Sharonaliza is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Sharonaliza owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector, operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Sharonaliza has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Sharonaliza joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Sharonaliza has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase new items to expand product offerings. Sharonaliza is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Sharonaliza from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Maurine

texts.en:
Maurine A. N. is a married lady with one child aged 3 years. Her business is located at Manyatta, a busy market in Kisumu. Kisumu is in Nyanza province and borders western Kenya. The region is well-known for production of tilapia and omena fish from Lake Victoria.  

She sells such food items as omena fish gotten from Lake Victoria. Other times, she makes doughnuts, which she sells to the local people. She has been in this kind of business for three years now. She says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has is lack of enough funds. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. 

She is using her loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to buy cooking oil and baking flour to expand her business. She hopes to have a mini-bakery in the future. She describes herself as hardworking and determined.

loans.use: Cooking oil and baking flour

loans.name: Safooran's Group

texts.en:
Safooran lives in Khanewal, which is a small city of Punjab, Pakistan, known for its agricultural industry. She is 48 years old and has three sons and two daughters. She couldn’t provide an education to her children due to the poor financial conditions of her family. 

Her eldest son has a barber shop and the next to him is a welder by profession and welds different machines on order. Her husband, F. S., is a laborer by profession. He is a very hard worker and his work involves a lot of physical energy. He is still very active at the age of 55. 

Safooran has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her son’s barber shop. With the loan, her son will buy scissors and hair-related products such as creams, gels and colors to provide better services to the clients. He has been doing this business for the past four years and Safooran is hopeful that this investment will prove successful for his business.
 
She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her third loan application. In previous years, she has proved herself as a very responsible client who paid her installments on time and never missed any meetings.
 
Note: In the photo, the lady who is holding a book (called the Asasah Passbook) in her hands is Safooran.

loans.use: To buy hair-related products and scissors for a barber shop

loans.name: Sughran's Group

texts.en:
Sughran is a resident of Khanewal which is located in Punjab and famous for its agriculture industry in Paksitan. She is 30 years old and married to M. A., who has a business of selling groceries. He runs a grocery shop in the nearby market where he sells different daily use items to his customers. He has a good number of clients. 

Sughran is a housewife, stays at home and takes care of her house and family. She is the mother of 6 sons. Unfortunately, none of them could get an education due to poor financial condition.  Her first two sons work in a private organization while the third son works in a general store. Sughran wants to secure her family’s future that’s why she wants improvement in her husband’s business. 

For this reason, she has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan, he will stock more grocery items such as lentils, rice, cooking oil and spices etc in his shop. That will enable him in generating a good income from his business.   Sughran is confident that her husband’s business will be improved after making this investment. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 3rd loan application. In previous loan years, she has maintained a good credit rating and never missed any  meeting.  

Note: “In the photo, the lady who has holds a book (called Asasah Passbook) in her hands is Sughran”.

Kisumu is in Nyanza province and boarders Western Kenya. The region is well known for production of Tilapia fish and Omena from lake victoria. 

Benter owns a general store in which she sells such items as rice, sugar, cooking oil and detergents. She has been in this kind of business for three years now and sells to the local households. She says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has is low income as her customers thus cannot afford to buy the items frequently, hence slowing down stock movement. However she works very hard to keep her business doing well. She is using her loan of Kes 20,000 to buy more general items to grow her business. She also sees herself diversifying into agriculture and the fish export business. She describes herself as hardworking optimistic and motivated.
