She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell and for working capital

loans.name: Yen

texts.en:
Yen V., 61, is a widow who lives with her sister and one child in Prey Veng province. She works in construction and typically makes about US $5 every day. Her sister is a farmer who works for less than US $1 of profit per day.

Yen V.’s son is a construction worker building houses. He earns US $5 per day like his mother. Yen V. would like to take out a loan of US $1,000 to purchase construction tools for her son.

loans.use: To purchase construction tools.

loans.name: Cicilia

texts.en: Cicilia G. currently sells clothes and uses a sewing machine to design clothes and is requesting a loan to stock more clothes like bedsheets to sell. G. is 28 years old and married to a business man. She has only two children who both attend school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house.

loans.use: Stock more clothes like bedsheets to sell

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene L. is from the village of Poblacion, Lantapan, Bukidnon. She is 29 years old. Irene is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling household products like coffee, shampoo, bath soap and others in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately $125 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Irene joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used as working capital to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 1st loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to use as working capital to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Huy

texts.en: Huy S. is 41 years old and lives with her husband and two of her children in the Prey Veng province. She sells groceries and works as a local doctor in the village and is able to make about $3 of profit every day. Her husband is a local teacher and he earns $2 per day. Since this family spends a lot on transportation costs, Huy S. would like to take out a loan of $1200 to purchase a motorbike.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Saida

texts.en: Saida M. is currently in the business of selling clothes at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more clothes to sell. She is 35 years old and is married to a peasant. She has three children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to provide food for her family and at the same time pay the school fees for her children.

loans.use: Stock more clothes to sell

loans.name: Cymberly

texts.en:
Cymberly D. is from the village of Poblacion, Lantapan, Bukidnon. She is 26 years old. Cymberly is married and has two infant-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling household products like coffee, vinegar, soy sauce and canned goods in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately $125 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Cymberly joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell and as working capital. This will be her 1st loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell and as working capital

loans.name: Jane

texts.en: Jane Y. is currently in the business of selling clothes at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more clothes to sell.  Jane is 40 years old and is married to a peasant. She has four children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to support the family by providing necessary materials at home.

loans.use: Stock more clothes to sell

loans.name: Phorn

texts.en: Phorn V., 27, is married and lives with her husband in the Prey Veng province. She and her husband have a business of breaking and selling rock. On average, they are able to make $5 per day. Phorn V. has three young children living at home to support. She is asking for a loan of $1000 to buy a drill and more tools to break the rock.

loans.use: To purchase a drill

loans.name: Walter

texts.en:
Walter I. A. is a married man. His wife runs their retail shop. They have four children between the ages of thirteen and one year old to whom they hope to provide a good education to the university level. 

His business is located at a busy market center known as Cheptulu. He is served by Kakamega branch. He sells meat to the local residents, schools and hotels. He has been doing this business for fifteen years now and has four employees. He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he has is the risk of cows dying before slaughter. However he works very hard to keep his business doing well. 

He is using his loan of 60,000 KES to buy cows for slaughter so that he has meat to sell. He hopes to open another butchery in the same market. He also hopes to buy a pickup for transporting the cows. In the future, he sees himself owning a personal car. He describes himself as very hardworking and honest.

loans.use: To buy cows for slaughter

loans.name: Elsie

texts.en:
Elsie L. is from the village of Babahagon, Lantapan, Bukidnon. She is 31 years old. Elsie is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling canned goods, instant noodles and snack foods in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately $125 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Elsie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell and as working capital. This will be her 1st loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell and as working capital

loans.name: Segrena

texts.en: Segrena R. is currently in the business of selling tomatoes and onions and is requesting a loan to stock more of these to sell. Segrena is 40 years old and married to a peasant. She has five children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her business.

loans.use: Stock more tomatoes and onions to sell

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan E., from the village of Poblacion, Lantapan, Bukidnon, is 56 years old, married and has nine grown children. To make a living, Susan owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling food products including snacks and biscuits and home products such as bath soaps and shampoo in the local community. Engaged in her business for over two years, she earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Susan joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Now requesting her first loan for 5000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell and use as working capital, she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her store.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Working capital and to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: The Kiva borrower is a 23-year-old single man from Lebanon who lives with his parents and two siblings. This talented young man has owned a metal shop in his town since 2007.  Lebanese families work together to meet the needs of the life, and this is certainly the case of the borrower who helps his father with the household.  Today, he is requesting a loan of $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase a large quantity of metal wholesale to increase his work operation. In the future, he hopes to open a commercial center to sell metal.

loans.use: To purchase a large quantity of metal wholesale

loans.name: Pek

texts.en: Pek B., 52, a widowed farmer who lives with her four children in Prey Veng Province, typically makes about US$2 each day, and her four children are employed. The weather conditions have been difficult in Cambodia this past year, and inflation has also been out of control. These factors have resulted in a difficult  year economically for many Cambodians, Pek B. included.  Since this family spends a great deal on transportation, Pek would like to take out a loan of US$1200 to purchase a motorbike for her children to commute to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Kwaje

texts.en: Kwaje B.  is currently in the business of selling clothes at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more clothes to sell.  Twenty-years-old and married to a driver, she has two children, both of whom go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, Kwaje hopes to be able to provide for the needs of her family.

loans.use: To stock more clothes to sell

loans.name: Wenifreda

texts.en:
Wenifreda M. is from the village of Poblacion, Lantapan, Bukidnon. She is 43 years old. Wenifreda is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Wenifreda owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling food and household products like canned goods, instant noodles, snacks, soap, toothpaste and detergents. Wenifreda has been engaged in her business for more than four years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Wenifreda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Wenifreda is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell and as working capital. This will be the first loan taken by Wenifreda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell and as working capital

loans.name: Fredolyn

texts.en:
Fredolyn R. is from the village of Luna. She is 35 years old. Fredolyn is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Fredolyn owns and operates a general store. Fredolyn has been engaged in her business for more than a year and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Fredolyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Fredolyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Fredolyn is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the second loan taken by Fredolyn from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Cheung

texts.en: Cheung R., 38, has two young children living at home to support. She and her family live in the Prey Veng province. To earn a living, she has been selling porridge and is able to make about US $1 of profit every day. Her husband is a moto-taxi driver. On average, he makes US $5 per day. Cheung R. is asking for a loan of US $1000 to replace an old and unreliable motorbike for her husband. The old motorbike usually needs fixing and uses a lot of gas.

loans.use: To replace an old motorbike.

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali H. M. is 38 years old, married and has five children between 18 and 4 years old. He hopes to give them a good education to the university level. His business is located at a busy market area known as Likoni in Mombasa, Kenya. Mombasa is the coastal region of Kenya and is well known for its many, many tourist attractions including the white beaches on the Indian Ocean. 

Ali has been selling cereals such as maize, beans, sorghum and peas for the last five years to the local people. He says that this business is profitable but the major challenge is that so many people are doing the same kind of business as his in the area that customers are spoiled for choice. However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well. He is using his loan of KES 20,000 to buy more cereals to expand his business while meeting his customers' demands. He hopes to be a supplier of cereals in the future. He also hopes to expand his business to be able to sustain his family. He describes himself as humble.

loans.use: To buy more maize, beans, sorghum and peas to resell

loans.name: Perisi

texts.en: Perisi N. is 34 years old and is married to a businessman. She has four children and her children go to school. Perisi is currently in the business of selling beer and soda and is requesting a loan to stock more crates of beer and soda to sell. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her business.

loans.use: To stock more crates of beer and soda to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Svay

texts.en: Svay S., 28, is married and lives with her husband and one young child in Phnom Penh. She and her husband grow and sell morning glory (water spinach). They usually earn a combined income of $16 US each day. This couple has been in this business since 2000. Svay S. is asking for a loan of $1000 US to purchase fertilizer and seed and to rent more land to grow morning glory. She hopes it will bring her family more income. Svay S.'s husband is in the photo.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and seed and rent more land to grow morning glory

loans.name: Nyakiju Tukore A, Rukungiri Group

texts.en:
Hard-working K. Naboth has, over the years, been operating a cattle fattening farm in Nyakiju cell, Rukungiri. He sells cows at the periodic markets that take place in Western Uganda. He purchases livestock directly, raises it on his farm and then finds a ready market for it supplying to butchers, hotels and other customers in the periodic markets. He also operates agricultural farms from which he generates income out of food crops like bananas, beans and maize.

The main drawbacks in his business have been unstable market prices and low capital input. With hard work and efficient customer care skills, he has managed to keep his business going for over 7 years. In a month, he makes profits to the tune of 400,000 Ugandan shillings.
 
His future plans are to expand his business transactions and to restock his farm. This will earn him more revenue to pay for his children’s education  and to improve their standard of living. With this loan, he anticipates great strides forward in achieving this dream and in restocking more cattle for sale.

loans.use: to restock his farm with cattle

loans.name: Moneka

texts.en: Moneka S. is currently in the business of selling onions and bread and is requesting a loan to stock more onions and some tomatoes to sell. Moneka is 45 years old and is married to a businessman. She has three children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy more home utensils for brewing and water tanks.

loans.use: To stock more onions and some tomatoes to sell

loans.name: Cicilia

texts.en: Cicilia Y. is currently in the business of selling beans, maize, etc., and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of maize and maize flour to sell. Cicilia is 30 years old and married to a policeman. She has two children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for rental.

loans.use: To stock more bags of maize and maize flour to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To expand and progress her business

loans.name: Martha

texts.en: Martha M. is 40 years old, single and has two children, ages 17 and 10 years old, whom she hopes to give a good education to the university level. Her business is located in a busy market known as Likoni in Mombasa, Kenya. Her business is well known by the name of "Gathoni Salon and Boutique". Mombasa is in the coastal region of Kenya and is well known for its many, many tourist attractions sites; not forgetting the white beaches of the Indian Ocean. Martha's salon provides hair and beauty services mostly to the local women. Besides the salon, she also has a boutique in which she sells clothes and ladies accessories. She has been in this business for six years now and has one employee. She says that this business is lacking enough capital; however, she works very hard from early morning to late evening to keep her business doing well. She is using her loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to buy more clothes to boost the boutique business, especially as we approach the Christmas festivities. She hopes to grow her business and open other branches within Mombasa. She describes herself as a simple but determined woman.

loans.use: To buy clothes

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose S.  is currently in the business of selling clothes at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more shoes and tomatoes to sell.  

Rose is 25 years old and married to a peasant. She has no children yet. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

loans.use: Stock more shoes and tomatoes to sell

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Regina C. is currently in the business of selling sugar, beer and soda at a shop and is requesting a loan to stock more crates of beer and soda to sell.  

Regina is 22 years old and married to a farmer. She has no children yet. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her business.

loans.use: Stock more crates of beer and soda to sell

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 38-year-old married man. He is living with his wife and two school-age children. He has been working as a traveling salesman, distributing food products to the local mini markets and grocery stores. He has been involved in this type of occupation for the past five years. He works independently.  

Today, he is requesting to borrow $700 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to increase his purchases, in order to increase his sales and his income. In the future, he is planning to open shop from which to sell food, expand his business operation and start working with new companies.

loans.use: To increase his purchases

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To improve her husband's vending business

loans.name: Ann

texts.en:
Ann N. is a single woman with one child who is two-and-a-half years old. Her business is located in Uhuru market in Nairobi. She sells handbags to the local people. She says that she has been in this business for eight years, and she is happy because the business has grown and people come to buy from her in bulk to resell. She says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has is the fact that the business is very seasonal. During high seasons, for example, over the holidays, she makes lots of money, but other times, her inventory moves slowly, decreasing her income. 

Ann works very hard every day from early morning to late evening to keep her business doing well. She is using her loan of Kes 70,000 to buy more handbags, in order to expand her business while meeting her customers' demands. She hopes to grow her business to a point where she can import bags and also export to other countries. She describes herself as hardworking and humble.

loans.use: To buy more handbags for resale

loans.name: Eleanor

texts.en:
Eleanor S. is from the town of Surallah. She is 53 years old. Eleanor is married and has six children. She is a farmer who plants and harvests rice crops. She also plants fruits, like pomelo, on some parts of her land. Eleanor is happy to share that she now has a sari-sari (general) store where she sells a variety of different products. She also sells her harvest of rice and fruit at her store.

Eleanor joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Eleanor has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Eleanor is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers and additional merchandise to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to their house.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers for her farm, and additional merchandise to sell at her general store

loans.name: Ropani

texts.en:
Ropani S. is currently in the business of selling medical drugs at the medical clinic and is requesting a loan to stock more drugs to sell. Ropani is 25 years old and is married to a businessman. They do not have any children. 

With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build some wards for admitting patients.

loans.use: Stock more medical drugs to sell

loans.name: C2361 Abishyizehamwe Group

texts.en:
Jaqueline is 29 years old and married with two children: the first one is 5 years old and the last one is 1 and a half years old. Jaqueline also takes care of two dependent relatives. In her family, there is a driver, who helps Jaqueline care for her family. Jaqueline owns a small business selling various vegetables and fruits. In addition, Jaqueline is the leader of a group of five people with various businesses.

Jaqueline and her group are requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company to expand their businesses by purchasing more products needed by their customers. With this loan, the group members will be able to sort out their family problems and their businesses as well.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria S. is currently in the business of selling fish at the market and is requesting a loan to stock some tomatoes and more fish to sell.  Victoria is 25 years old and is married to a peasant. 

With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

loans.use: Stock more fish to sell and also tomatoes

loans.name: Lun

texts.en:
Lun L. is 31 years old and lives in Phnom Penh with his wife and two young children. Since 2003, he has been operating a moto-taxi, a motorbike with a trailer attached. On average, he is able to make about $7 of profit every day, while his wife is a garment factory worker, making $3 a day. 

To earn more income, Lun L. is asking for a loan of $700 to open a coffee shop.

loans.use: To open a coffee shop

loans.name: Violet

texts.en:
Violet A. is a single woman with no children. Her business is located at a busy market called Jericho, in Nairobi, and the business is well known by the name Baraka Electronics and Phone Accessories. She sells electronics and phone accessories to the local people. She says that she has been in this business for three years, and before getting into the business, she was also employed. 

She says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has is debtors who do not pay as per the agreement. However, she works very hard every day from early morning to late evening to keep her business doing well. She is using her loan of Kes 40,000 to boost her inventory in order to expand her business while meeting her customers demands. She hopes to grow her business and open another one. She sees herself importing a whole container from china or Dubai. She describes herself as beautiful, hardworking and smart.

loans.use: To increase her inventory of chargers, speakers, batteries, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine for her business

loans.name: Joice

texts.en:
Joice K. is currently in the business of selling various foodstuffs at a restaurant and is requesting a loan to stock more foodstuffs to cook and sell in the restaurant.  

Joice is 37 years old and is married to a farmer. She has five children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to extend the floor of her restaurant.

loans.use: Stock more foodstuffs to cook and sell in the restaurant

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 56-year-old married man who has three children, one of whom attends school. 

He is the main income provider for his family. He has 25 years of experience working as a farmer, and he has been running his own farm since 1990. He cultivates all types of vegetables and fruit on his land, according to the season. He also uses plastic tents to grow his products. These tents also allow him to better monitor product quality, as well as grow his products for more months during the year. He works independently in his business. He distributes the harvest to a local agriculture market. 

Today, he is requesting a loan of $1,000 to purchase needed supplies for his agricultural work. He estimates that his profit has the potential to increase by 18% after taking the loan.

loans.use: To purchase needed supplies for his agricultural work

loans.name: Lucya

texts.en: Lucya M. is currently in the business of selling simsim, onions and phase and is requesting a loan to stock more onions and bags of simsim to sell. Lucya is 50 years old and is married with a husband that is a deminer. She has four children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand the business.

loans.use: Stock more onions and bags of simsim to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To expand her husband's bakery business

loans.name: Dawa

texts.en:
Dawa J. is currently in the business of selling sugar, salt, soap, cooking oil, etc., and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of sugar and cartons of salt to sell.  

Dawa is 30 years old and is married to a businessman. She has six children, and three of her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to further expand her business.

loans.use: Stock more bags of sugar and cartons of salt to sell

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose A. is currently in the business of selling beans, onions, etc., at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of beans and onions to sell.  

Rose is 36 years old and is married to a farmer. She has five children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

loans.use: Stock more bags of beans and onions to sell

loans.name: Adolatmo

texts.ru: Миралиева Адолатмо жительница города Душанбе. Возраст, 52 года. Вдова, имеет 3 детей. Сын на заработках в России. Сама Адолатмо предоставляет услугу, то есть она занимается шитьем. Она в основном шьет национальные платья. Берет заказы на дому. В этой области уже 7 лет. Кредит берет для покупки компьютерной швейной машинки.
texts.en: Adolatmo M. lives in the city of Dushanbe.  She is 52 years old, a window and has 3 children.  Her son works in Russia.  Adolatmo provides services, i.e. she is involved in sewing.  She primarily makes national dresses.  She does her orders at home.  Adolatmo has been in this field for 7 years.  She is requesting this loan for the purchase of a sewing machine.

loans.use: Purchase of a sewing machine

loans.name: Alhamdulilai Group

texts.en:
In the photo are members of the “Alhamdulilai” Group. They are entrepreneurs running small scale businesses based in Makeni, a city in Northern Sierra Leone. This is the first loan these entrepreneurs are accessing from SMT/Kiva lenders. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more profit and consequently improve their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Fatmata T.. Fatmata is age 45. She was born in Makeni city where she now lives with her husband and five children. Her husband is a teacher and one of her children is attending secondary school. For 22 years now, Fatmata has been selling fried food and breads. She will use her share of this loan to expand her business by buying bread, eggs, etc.

loans.use: To buy bread, eggs, etc.

loans.name: Chamshed

texts.ru: Бозоров Чамшед проживает в городе Душанбе. Возраст, 28 лет. Холост. Образование высшее, бухгалтер. По профессии проработал 3 года. Сейчас он работает на рынке. Продает пирожное и печенье. Этим видом занимается уже год. Кредит берет для увеличения ассортимента товара. Чамшед хочет расширить свой бизнес.
texts.en: Chamshed B. lives in the city of Dushanbe.  He is 28 years old, single.  He has a higher education, as an accountant.  Chamshed worked 3 years in his field.  Currently, he works at a market, selling pastries and cookies.  He has been involved in this business for one year.  He is requesting this loan in order to expand product selection.  Chamshed wants to expand his business.

loans.use: Expanding product selection

loans.name: Mena Group Iv

texts.en:
Jatu K. is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Jatu was born in Makeni, a city in Northern Sierra Leone, about 49 years ago. She is married to a driver and the couple has five children. One of her children is still attending secondary school.

For many years now, Jatu has been selling dishes, cloths, etc. This is the first loan that Jatu and her group members are accessing from SMT/Kiva lenders. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions. Jatu will use her share of the loan (800,000 leones) to buy a large quantity of stock.

loans.use: To buy dishes, cloths, etc.

loans.name: Ta - Taesu - Tekeh Group

texts.en:
Meet the members of the “Ta-Taesu-Tekeh” group from Makeni, a city in Northern Sierra Leone. They are all local entrepreneurs who have come to SMT, a Kiva partner, to apply for a loan of 800,000 leones each. With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions. 

Isatu L. is the leader of this group. She is a 50-year-old woman, married to an Imam, and they have four children who are no longer attending schools. Isatu has been a businesswoman for many years now. She sells soft drinks, etc. With her share of this loan, she will buy crates of soft drinks to add to her business.

loans.use: To buy crates of soft drinks to add to her business

loans.name: Tity- Pain Group

texts.en: Pictured here are members of the “Tity Pain” group from Makeni, a city in Northern Sierra Leone. They are businesswomen who have come to SMT, a Kiva partner, seeking a loan of 1,000,000 leones each. With this loan, they will be able to add more goods to their businesses, attract more customers, make more sales and profit, and consequently improve their living conditions. The leader of this group of entrepreneurs is Sarah M.. Sarah was born in Kabala town. She is 32 years old, married and has two children. Her husband is a police officer and her children are attending primary school. Sarah has been selling drinks, top-up cards for all four mobile networks, and gara lapper (locally dyed cloths) for many years now. She will invest her share of the loan into her business by buying drinks, top-up cards and gara cloths to add to her business.

loans.use: To buy drinks, top-up cards and gara cloth

loans.name: Glenny

texts.en:
Glenny D. is from the village of Puerta, Lurugan, Valencia City, Bukidnon. She is 35 years old and married with six school-aged children. To make a living, Glenny owns and operates a retail store, buying and selling ready to wear clothing and shoe products in the local community. She is also engaged in selling Natasha and Avon products. Glenny has been in business for over seven years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Glenny joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Glenny has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding the business. Glenny is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Glenny from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and working capital

loans.name: Honesty Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the Honesty Group. They run small scale businesses based in Makeni, a city in Northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of 800,000 leones each to enable them to further expand their businesses. Consequently, they will make more profit and improve their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Bai K. who is in the middle. Bai is age 28 and was born in Makeni city. He is single with no children. Bai has been a businessman for two years now. He runs a telephone booth. With his share of this loan, he will buy top-up cards for all four mobile companies, mobile phone accessories, etc., to sell in his telephone booth.

loans.use: To buy top-up cards for all four mobile companies, mobile phone accessories, etc. to sell

loans.name: Sorie

texts.en:
This is 42 year-old Sorie Kamara. He is married, and has three children who are 9, 10, and 16 years old. 

In 1991, Sorie established his wood and palm oil business. He began his business to generate income and facilitate his children's education. Working seven days a week and nine hours a day, he earns about Le 1,800,000 every month from this business and is very hardworking. 

He would like a loan in the amount of Le 3,000,000. Sorie requires a loan in order to buy seven trips of wood and 22 rubbers of palm oil.  He hopes that this loan will enable him to increase his monthly profits by approximately Le 250,000.  In the future, Sorie plans to build a house for his family and continue educating his children to university level. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy more items such as palm oil and wood for his stall

loans.name: Novelyn

texts.en:
Novelyn V. is from the village of Lilingayon, Valencia City. She is 37 years old and married with three school-aged children. To make a living, Novelyn owns and operates a business buying and selling ready to wear clothing and shoes in the local community. She is also engaged in selling Natasha and Avon products. Novelyn has been in business for over five years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Novelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Novelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Novelyn is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Novelyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and working capital

loans.name: Tufosa

texts.en:
Tufosa is 31 years old from Nyamasare area in Migori town, and she is married to Herman. They have five children who are all in lower primary schools.

Tufosa is in the business of selling medicines and many people prefer to buy from her since she is fairly cheap, compared to the pharmacies around. She is applying for her first loan from KADET LTD  after being introduced to KADET by a friend who is also a client here. Tufosa wants to use the money to buy different types of medicines, such as painkilliers, antibiotics, cough syrup, etc., to add to her stock.

Her hope is one day to be able to open a pharmacy as her business grows.

loans.use: Buy stocks of medicine

loans.name: Momodu's Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Kiva.org in Makeni, northern Sierra Leone, is pleased to present to you the teachers of the Khulafai Rashideen Primary School. This school was founded on the 20th of September 1999 by the Khulafai Rashideen Mission in order to reduce the problems of overcrowding in the then-existing schools. The Khulafai Rashideen Primary school currently has twenty-four dedicated teachers and eight hundred pupils.   

This is not the first loan that teachers of this institution have borrowed from SMT/Kiva lenders. The previous SMT/Kiva loan made a lot of improvements in the lives of these borrowers. “This new loan will further improve the livelihood of our staff members,” said Momodu K., the leader of this group and headmaster at the school. The forty-seven-year-old Momodu was born in Port Loka, a town in northern Sierra Leone.  He has been in the teaching profession for twenty-six years now. Momodu is married to a businesswoman, and they have ten children – eight in primary school and two in secondary school.  Momodu K. is going to invest his share of this loan into a business. He will buy local produce to sell. 

School staff from this institution, like many other schools staff within SMT’s operational areas, comes to SMT to apply for loans. With the help of these loans, they can accomplish certain tasks that they would otherwise have not been able to accomplish with their mere salaries alone. With the help of this loan, some can pay school fees for their children; others can use the loan to buy pieces of furniture, a plot of land, or house-building materials; still others invest in business. At the end of each month, these teachers can repay the loan out of their monthly salaries. The institution’s bursar is directly responsible for deducting the repayment and pays SMT on their behalf.

loans.use: To buy local produce to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To add more stock and raw materials for her business

loans.name: Simon

texts.en:
Simon A. is 37 years old. He is from Nyalenda in Kisumu city. He is married to Hannah, who is a fishmonger, and they have four children between 8 and 15 years old. 

Simon has a motorcycle business that he has been running for the past three years. He is applying for his first loan from KADET  LTD. He needs to buy spare parts for his motorcycle to enable him to transport people well from one place to another. His monthly income is 15,000 Kenyan shillings. He hopes to make a lot of profit to enable him to get a rickshaw to add to his motorcycle business.

His hope is to have an established transport business and to see his business really grow.

loans.use: Buy motorcycle spare parts

loans.name: Amie

texts.en:
This is Amie. She is married and has five children, aged 4, 8, 10, 12, and 18 years. In 2000, Amie established her used-clothing business. She began her business by buying additional goods like vests, skirts, body suits and trousers.  

Working 7 days a week and 10 hours a day, she earns about 750,000 Sierra Leone Leones (Le) every month from this business. She would like a loan in the amount of Le 4,000,000 to increase her business capital. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately Le 400,000.  

In the future, Amie plans to educate her children to the university level, buy land and establish a savings account for retirement. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: Buy more used clothing for her business

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena E. is from the village of Quezon, Bukidnon. She is 53 years old. Elena is married and has 12 adult children. To make a living, Elena owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling daily-use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, biscuits, and snacks in the local community. Elena has been engaged in her business for more than ten years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Elena joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Elena has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Elena is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Elena from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more assorted clothing for her business,

loans.name: C2143 Umuseke Group

texts.en:
Solange is 22 years old and single; however, she has to contribute to her family even though she is single. Solange tries to provide all the necessities for her family. She owns a business selling various foodstuffs. She has one and a half years' experience and she employs one person as help. The hours of her daily activities are from 6 in the morning to 9 in the evening every day except on Saturday. In addition, Solange is the leader of this group of five people with different businesses:  some of them sell foodstuffs; restaurant and so on.

Solange and her group are now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company. She will purchase additional products for her store. With this loan, the members of group will be able to satisfy their customers and will be able to be more effective and more efficient.

loans.use: To purchase additional foodstuffs

loans.name: Philip Kibet

texts.en:
Philip C. is 35 years old and married to Christine Chelangat. They have two children: Brian (four years old) and Janeth (two years old). 

Philip is a tailor in Serem town and has been in this business for the past six years. He is applying for his fourth loan from KADET LTD. He has a good credit history with us through the years. He is in need of fabrics to have on hand. His tailoring shop is in a rural village market and he specializes in school uniforms and women's dresses. 

He hopes to expand his tailoring business and establish a tailoring training center.

loans.use: To purchase fabric

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy assorted food items for her stall such as pepper, groundnuts, etc.

loans.name: Conchita

texts.en:
Conchita B. is from the village of Salawagan, Quezon, Bukidnon. She is 60 years-old and married with five adult children. To make a living, Conchita owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling ready to wear clothing and shoe products in the local community. Conchita has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Conchita joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Conchita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Conchita is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and to provide working capital. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Conchita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to provide working capital.

loans.name: Baby

texts.en: This is 36 year-old Baby S..  She is married and has two children aged eight and 12 years.  In 2006, Baby established her palm oil and rice selling business.  She began her business to generate enough income in order to educate children.  Working seven days a week and nine hours a day, she earns about Le 750,000 every month from this business. She would like a loan in the amount of Le 3,000,000.  Baby requires a loan in order to buy palm oil and rice.  She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately Le 300,000. In the future, Baby plans to establish a savings account, educate her children to university level and construct a house.  She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy more plam oil and rice.

loans.name: Ibrahim's Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Kiva.org in Makeni, northern Sierra Leone, is pleased to present to you teachers of the Kankalay Islamic Primary School. This school was founded in 1992 by the Kankalay Mission as a response to the community’s request for an educational center in the community. The Kankalay Islamic Primary School is currently staffed with 15 teachers and has an enrollment of 350 pupils.

Thirty-six-year-old Ibrahim D. is the leader of this group and headmaster at the school. Ibrahim was born in a village called Royainkain in northern Sierra Leone.  He has been in the teaching profession for 10 years now. He is married and has four children. Three of the children are in primary school and one is in secondary school. Ibrahim is going to invest his share of this loan in business. He will buy locally-produced goods such as rice and palm oil at wholesale to sell. 

This is the first loan that teachers of this school are accessing from SMT/Kiva lenders. School staff from this institution, like many other schools staff within SMT’s operational areas, come to SMT to apply for loans. With the help of these loans, they can accomplish certain tasks that they would otherwise have not being able to accomplish with their mere salaries alone. But with the help of this loan, some can pay school fees for their children; others can use the loan to buy pieces of furniture, a plot of land, house-building materials, or to invest in business. At the end of each month, these teachers can repay the loan out of their monthly salaries. The institution’s bursar is directly responsible for deducting the repayment and pays SMT on their behalf.

loans.use: To buy locally-produced goods such as rice and palm oil at wholesale to sell

loans.name: Vicenta

texts.en:
Vicenta P. is from the village of Puerta, Lurugan, Valencia City. She is 44 years-old and married with seven school-aged children. To make a living, Vicenta owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste as well as biscuits and junk food in the local community. Vicenta has been engaged in her business for over 21 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Vicenta joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Vicenta has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Vicenta is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and to provide working capital. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Vicenta from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to provide working capital.

loans.name: Martha Otembo

texts.en:
Martha O. is a 23 year-old unmarried woman from Luanda area which is not far from Vihiga town. She lives alone but supports her siblings and parents from the income she earns from her business.

Martha has a clothes store that she has had for the past three years.  From it, she earns an income of Kshs 14,000 per month. She is applying for her second loan from Kiva partner KADET Ltd. after successfully completing the first one. She intends to use the money to buy five bails of new clothes to add to her stock. The profits made will basically be used to pay school fees for her siblings and to expand her capital base.

Her dream is to see her business expand and to purchase a textile machine.

loans.use: Buy  five  bails of clothes

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth K. is 32 years-old, unmarried and without any children. Her business is located at Kwa Hola Magongo Estate in Mombasa, Kenya. Mombasa is in the coastal region of Kenya and is well known for its many many tourist attraction sites not least of which are the Indian ocean white beaches.

Ruth has been selling items as rice, flour, oil,detergents, soft drinks and other items  for the last eleven years to local people. She says that this business is profitable but the major challenge is that there are so many people doing the same kind of business as hers in the area and customers are spoilt for choice. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. She is using her loan of Kes 80,000 to buy more general items to expand her business. She hopes to be a wholesaler in the future. She describes herself as welcoming and jovial.

loans.use: To purchase rice, flour, cooking fat, detergents etc

loans.name: Angelito

texts.en:
Angelito R. is from the village of Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro City. He is 27 years-old and married with three school-aged children. To make a living, Angelito owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes  from buying and selling fish products such as milk fish, anduhaw, gutob, budlisan and galong-gong in the local community. Angelito has been engaged in his business for over two years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Angelito joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Angelito is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fish o buy and sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Angelito from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional fish.

location.town: Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph N. is 40 years-old and from Kisumu city. He is married to Addah and they have one child called Michelle who is two years old. They live in Kisumu city.

For the last three years, Joseph has had a transport business. He owns a Nissan that is the main form of transport here in Kisumu.  He is applying for his first loan of Kshs 30,000. He needs the money to be able to buy spare parts. His monthly income comes to Kshs 12,000.

He desires to grow his business and improve the standard of living for the family.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts.

loans.name: Margie

texts.en:
Margie B. is from the village of Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 24 years-old and married with a baby.  To make a living, Margie owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste as well as biscuits, breads, and junk food in the local community. Margie has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Margie joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Margie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Margie is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and to provide working capital. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Margie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to provide working capital.

location.town: Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Martha K.'s Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Kiva.org in Makeni, northern Sierra Leone, is pleased to present to you teachers of the National Penticostal Primary School. This school was founded on September 19, 1994 by the National Penticostal Mission to educate the children of the community. National Penticostal Primary school is staffed with nine able teachers and 380 pupils.  

This is the first loan that this school has applied for from SMT/Kiva lenders. Martha K. S. is their leader and headmaster at the school. The 51-year-old Martha was born in Mabanta village, an outskirt of Makeni city. She has been in the teaching profession for 37 years now. She is married to a teacher and they have three children. Two of the children are in college and one is an adult. Mrs. S. has requested this loan in order to pay college fees for her children. 

School staff from this institution, like many other schools staff within SMT’s operational areas, come to SMT to apply for loans. With the help of these loans, they can accomplish certain tasks that they would otherwise have not been able to accomplish with their mere salaries alone. But with the help of this loan, some can pay school fees for their children; others can use the loan to buy pieces of furniture, a plot of land, house-building materials, or to invest in business. At the end of each month, these teachers can repay the loan out of their monthly salaries. The institution’s bursar is directly responsible for deducting the repayment and pays SMT on their behalf.

loans.use: To pay college fees for her children

loans.name: C2362 Abizeranye Group

texts.en:
Adela is 45 years old and married with six children between the ages of 15 and 28. Adela also takes care of two dependent relatives. With this big family, Adela provides all the necessities because no one else in her family works. Adela is a business woman selling various foodstuffs such as beans, maize, and so on. Adela is seasoned in her business because she has 10 years of experience. The hours of her business are from 5 in the morning to 6 in the evening. Adela is also the group representative for five people with different businesses. 

Adela and her group are requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company to expand their businesses by purchasing different products needed by their customers. With this loan, Adela and her group will be able to earn enough profit to help them sort out their business problems and their family problems as well.

loans.use: To expand the business

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty B. is from the village of Baluarte, Lumbia, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 52 years-old and married with three adult children. To make a living, Betty owns and operates a business making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from making and selling snacks and other delicacies such as rice cakes and cassava cakes in the local community. She is also buying and selling dried fish.. Betty has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Betty joined Kiva partnerHSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Betty has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Betty is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and to provide working capital. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Betty from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to provide working capital.

location.town: Baluarte, Lumbia, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose A. is 43 years old from Migori town and is a widow, as her husband died ten years ago. She has a daughter who is 18 years old and in college.

Rose is a charcoal dealer and has been doing this business for the past 13 years. She is applying for her first loan from KADET LTD and hopes that this will boost her business and enable her grow it to greater heights.  She intends to use the money to buy more charcoal from a different source, as the current supplier has hiked up the prices of charcoal.

Her hope is to see her business expand and even to be able to employ a person to help her manage it.

loans.use: To buy ten sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Cecilia Wanjeri

texts.en:
Cecilia has practiced farming in Olkalou town for the last ten years. She is 26 years old and married to Patrick Gichuki. They have one child.

She was introduced to KADET by her friend and this will be her second loan. She repaid her first loan in full and in good time. She plans to use this loan amount to harvest and plant potatoes in her farm.

In future Cecilia hopes to open up a clothes shop in Olkalou town. This will diversify her source of income.

loans.use: To harvest and plant more potatoes in her farm.

loans.name: Asucena Group

texts.es:
El comité  Asucena ” se formó con la unión de varias vecinas de la ciudad de Yryvukua.
 Todas las integrantes del comité desarrollan actividades independientes, como son las ventas, preparación de comidas rápidas, cría de animales etc. 
Las integrantes formaron un grupo muy unido y capaz de realizar conjuntamente actividades que fortalecen su compañerismo. 
Este comité ya están en su tercer ciclo, todo este tiempo demostraron puntualidad, solidaridad y  unión entres las compañeras.
	La  Sra. Angela A. es una de las integrantes de la ciudad de Yryvukua, del Barrio centro tiene 60 años de edad, está casada con el Sr. Osvaldo  con 68 años de edad, Actualmente tiene 8 Hijos, todos  mayores de edad.
 
       Posee una despensa en su domicilio, señora muy trabajadora.

             La Sra. con este crédito está pensando comprar más mercaderías como fideos, arroz, azúcar, panificados para la venta y así tener mejor ingreso.
texts.en:
The Asucena committee was formed by a union of various neighbors in the city of Yrkvukua.

All of the members of the committee have developed independent jobs; some are vendors, others prepare fast food, others raise animals, etc. The members form a very united group and are able to carry out joint activities to improve their partnership.

This committee is in their third loan cycle and all have shown themselves to be punctual and show solidarity and unity between members.

Angela A. is one of the members from the city of Yryvukua, from the central neighborhood. She is 60 years old and married to Mr. Osvaldo who is 68 years old. They have eight children, all grown.

She runs a store out of her home and is a very hardworking woman.

With this loan Angela is thinking about buying more products like noodles, rice, sugar, and baked goods to sell and make more income.

loans.use: Buying noodles, sugar, rice, baked goods, and other products

loans.name: Joseph Otieno

texts.en:
Joseph O. is 30 years old and married to Rehema Atieno. They have six children who are all in primary school. They live in Kamenya, a town on the outskirts of Migori town.

Joseph owns a shop and has seen his business grow through the years. He needs a loan to help him boost the business even further. He wants to buy some crates of soda, wheat flour, margarine and sugar to add to his stock. He has a huge clientele, as his shop is in the rural area and is the only one there, so people come from afar to buy things from his shop. He intends to use the profits to buy an ox to help him with ploughing, as he is also a farmer.

He has a desire to improve his shop and to buy a grinding machine (Posho Mill) to run alongside his business.

loans.use: To buy wheat flour, margarine, sugar and crates of soda to add to his stock.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth B. is from the village of Baluarte, Lumbia, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 40 years old. Elizabeth is married and has three school-age children.  Elizabeth owns a specialized retail store in which her main source of income is generated primarily from buying and selling coconut oil in the local community. Elizabeth has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Elizabeth joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elizabeth is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Elizabeth from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to continue to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and for working capital

location.town: Baluarte, Lumbia, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is a married woman with four children, three of whom attend school while the other is still too young for school. She lives at a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are school fees and house rent. 

She has operated her business of selling sukuma wiki (green vegetables) and clothes from her home to her neighbors and passersby. Rose faces the major challenge of competition in her business as many people sell similar products. She hopes to purchase a boda boda (motorcycle) for transport in the future. 

With the 40,000 KES she wants to purchase two bales of clothes for resale. Rose decided to join Yehu because of its good reputation in the community.

loans.use: To purchase two bales of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Haja

texts.en:
This is 28-year-old Haja.  She is married and has two children, ages 12 and nine. She has two additional dependents, who live with her because she needs them to help her with her domestic work while she is selling.

In 2005, Haja established her food items and household utensil business.  She began her business to generate enough income to support her husband and provide a livelihood for them so they can educate their children.  Her business is open seven days a week and 12 hours a day. Haja earns about 4,380,000 SLL every month from this business.  She would like a loan in the amount of 3,000,000 SLL to buy additional stock.  She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profit by approximately 657,000 SLL.  

In the future, Haja plans to develop her business and to help her family live a comfortable life.  She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy more household utensils for sale

loans.name: Salim

texts.en:
Salim Mohamed is a 44-year-old bicycle repairer and spare parts dealer in Kibaoni Kilifi. He is married to Said Mohamed who contributes to their income and together they have three children. He has been in this business for the last twenty years and has done well. 

He is now requesting his third loan with which he intends to purchase bicycle spare parts for resale. He will use the anticipated profit to buy a plot of land and build residential houses for rental.

In the future he would like to open up a retail shop for his spouse.

loans.use: To buy stock of bicycle spare parts for resale

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en:
Imelda P. is from the village of Baluarte, Lumbia, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 48 years old. Imelda is married and has five adult children. Imelda owns a specialized retail store in which the main source of income generated comes primarily from buying and selling green bananas in the local community. Imelda has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Imelda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Imelda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional bananas to buy and sell. Imelda is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. This loan will be the 5th loan taken out by Imelda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to continue to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and for working capital

location.town: Baluarte, Lumbia, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Dante

texts.en:
Dante B. is from the village of Baluarte, Lumbia, Cagayan de Oro City. He is 25 years old and single. To make a living, Dante has a venture planting and harvesting  potatoes for sale. He has been engaged in his business for over two years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month. 

In 2010, Dante joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI used to purchase fertilizer such as manure, and is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP to purchase seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. This will be the second loan taken out by Dante from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand his business. 

About HSPFI: HSPFI is accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and seedlings to raise

location.town: Baluarte, Lumbia, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: C2896 Dukore Group

texts.en:
Jeanne was born in 1983. She is married with two children. Jeanne owns a small business selling various products such as salt, rice, sugar, cosmetic products and so on. Jeanne has five years of experience. The hours of her daily activities are from 6 in the morning to 8 in the evening every day. Jeanne is the leader of a group of three people with different businesses. 

Jeanne and her group are requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company. She will purchase additional products needed by her customers. With this loan, Jeanne and other members of the group will be able to expand their business which is the best way to earn more profits.

loans.use: To purchase additional products for her store

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena B. is from the village of Baluarte, Lumbia, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 40 years old and married with ten school-aged children. Elena has made her living over the past two years buying and selling green bananas and firewood. She earns approximately 7000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Elena joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11000 PHP from HSPFI and is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Elena from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI: HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

location.town: Baluarte, Lumbia, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: The Kiva borrower is a 42-year-old married man with two young children attending school. He is an experienced carpenter of almost 15 years and has owned a carpentry shop since 2004. He works at the request of  clients and in collaboration with some galleries. Today, he is requesting $900 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase additionA. wood. He reports that this will help him increase his profits by a large percentage. In the future, he looks to further expand his business and invest in a new wood-sanding machine. He hopes that the coming year will continue to bring positive growth and increased sales.

loans.use: to purchase additional wood

loans.name: Margarate Nabusuba

texts.en:
Margarate Nabusuba J. is a 40 year-old food kiosk owner in Magongo, Mombasa. She is married to Patrick Makoko and they are blessed with three children. She has had her business for the last three years and has made a good income. 

She has applied for her second loan from KADET which she would like to use to carry out renovations on her kiosk and purchase more foodstuff. She will use  the anticipated profit to expand her business.

In future she hopes to open up a restaurant.

loans.use: Renovations to her food stall and food for her kiosk

loans.name: Maria Auxiliadora Group

texts.es:
El comité “Maria Auxiliadora” se formó con la unión de varias vecinas  de Capiibary-11 de septiembre. 
Todas las integrantes del comité desarrollan actividades independientes, como son las ventas, Despensa, cría de animales y otros.
  Las integrantes formaron un grupo muy unido y capaz de realizar conjuntamente actividades que fortalecen su compañerismo y al adquirir el crédito se le abren muchas puertas para el progreso de sus emprendimiento.
Germina R. Diaz Irala, es una de las integrantes quien es la presidenta del grupo.
